thread.title: Westminster cross country enters halfway mark
thread.title_full: Westminster cross country enters halfway mark

author: E. Marcel Pourtout mpourtout@neighbornewspapers.com (noreply@neighbornewspapers.com)
title: Westminster cross country enters halfway mark
text: Westminster cross country enters halfway mark by E. Marcel Pourtout October 07, 2015 05:21 PM | 637 views | 0 | 2 | | The Westminster cross country team participated in its first major meet of the season on Sept. 26 at the Atlanta Classic held at Clinton Farms in Douglas County.The girls’ team placed second overall in the standings, scoring 79 points. Huntsville High School finished first with 45 points.Three Wildcats’ runners placed in the top-15 in the girls’ race led by sophomore Delaney Graham who finished ninth with a time of 19:46.49. Teammate Victoria Flowers finished right behind her as the freshman ran the race in 19:46.50 for tenth place. Senior Margaret Maxwell’s time of 20:00.95 was good enough for 15th place. Sarah Foreman of Landmark Christian School won the individual competition with a time of 19:10.48The girls’ team is rounding into form as training continues for the region and state meets which will take place later in October.“Things are going well and the girls are running at the speed they need to be for this time of season,” girls’ coach Amy Eubanks said. “We’ve had some freshman and sophomores run well for us. There are also some girls coming back to the team that were injured last year. It’s exciting for us.”The boys’ team finished fifth at the Atlanta Classic with 137 points. Whitewater placed first in the team competition with 57 points followed by North Oconee, Bishop Kenny and Homeland High School.The Wildcats had two runners place in the top-25 in the boys’ race led by junior Jack Powers’ time of 17:16.09 which was good enough for 18th place and senior Clare Draper’s coming in 22nd place at 17:23.12.Westminster has one of the top prep cross country programs in the country with the girls’ team amassing 27 state titles while the boys’ squad has 25 state championships.“Our runners have a strong work ethic and push each other in practice,” Eubanks said. “We have good team camaraderie with 119 runners and that energy makes everyone excited to run. The students at Westminster are driven to work hard and like to be the best.”The Region 4AAA meet will be hosted by Westminster on Oct. 28 followed by the state meet in Carrollton on Nov. 7.
